page.title: 04COUNTY HALL, ABINGDON
page.content: The present County Hall had been preceded by at least three other buildings. In 1327 during a riot, the Abingdon people attacked the Abbey and destroyed the "New House on the Market Square". The hall was rebuilt, "a fair house, with open pillars covered with a roof of lead for market folk". It contained a courtroom, prison and a covered market. The present County Hall was built in 1686, when James 11 proclaimed Abingdon the county town of Berkshire. Restoration work took place between 1952-1956 and it was re-opened by Queen Elizabeth 11 in 1956. On Mondays, it is market day, and the County Hall has a few stalls, it now has a museum on the first floor. Bun throwing is done from the top of the County Hall.(see page 5). Written by Julia Fawcett aged 11 years.
